Description: A bird 'askos', probably a dove, with a funnel-shaped mouth rising from its back. The body is formed from a wheel-thrown pot, with the tail fashioned by pressing the mouth of the pot together and luting it closed. The neck and head of the bird were separately modelled, perhaps wheel-thrown and manipulated, and applied; the beak forms a spout. Pellets were added for eyes, and minuscule wings applied: one is lost. Brown Nile silt with many sand inclusions; much of the surface has fired buff.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased from Selima Harris, collector, a resident of Alexandria and daughter of the collector and dealer Anthony C. Harris. Probably late Roman, about fifth to sixth century AD.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3777)
